facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1003 and 1004 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1003 and 1004 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and orders dated November 13, 1958 of Bombay High Court in Miscellaneous Petition No. 217 and 218 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and orders dated November 13, 1958 of the Bombay High Court in Miscellaneous Petition No. 217 and 218 of 1958.

facts.text: 1st Income-tax Officer, C-11 Ward, Bombay served notice under s. 18-A(1) to Bhagwandas Kevaldas (assessee) to pay Rs. 25,973/5 as advance-tax for 1948-49 in four equal installments.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. The 1st Income-tax Officer, C-11 Ward, Bombay served a notice under s. 18-A(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 calling upon Bhagwandas Kevaldas-who will hereinafter be called the assessee-to pay in four equal installments Rs. 25,973/5 as advance-tax for the assessment year 1948-49.

facts.text: Assessee filed estimate of income under s. 18-A(2) on September 17, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On September 17, 1947 the assessee filed an estimate of his income under s. 18-A(2) and of the tax payable by him,

facts.text: Assessee filed revised estimate on January 10, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and on January 10, 1948 he filed a revised estimate.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer made provisional assessment under s. 23-B and assessee paid tax on August 23, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: An order under S. 23-B of the Act provisionally assessing the income was made by the Income-tax Officer and pursuant thereto on August 23, 1950 the assessee paid the tax so assessed.

facts.text: Regular assessment made on March 31, 1953; tax paid on estimate less than 80% of regular tax, but no interest charged under s.18-A(6).

anchor.surface_text: Regular assessment of the income of the assessee was made on March 31, 1953 by the Income-tax Officer, and it was found that the tax paid on the basis of the estimate of the assessee was less than eighty per cent of the tax determined as a result of the regular assessment. But the Income-tax Officer made no charge for interest under sub-s.(6) of S. 18-A of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Departmental auditor objected to failure to charge interest.

anchor.surface_text: The departmental auditor raised an objection in auditing accounts of C-11 Ward that a mistake was committed by the Income-tax Officer in failing to charge interest in making the order of assessment against the assessee.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer served notice on September 21, 1956 to show cause why rectify mistake and pay penal interest under s.18-A(6).

anchor.surface_text: On September 21, 1956 the Income-tax Officer served a notice upon the assessee requiring him to show cause why the mistake in not levying interest be not rectified and why he should not be directed to pay penal interest under s. 18-A(6).

facts.text: On October 4, 1956, Income-tax Officer rectified under s.35, issued demand for Rs. 14,929/10 interest from January 1, 1948 to July 22, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On October 4, 1956 the Income-tax Officer recorded the following order ... and served a notice of demand calling upon the assessee to pay Rs. 14,929/10 as interest due under s. 18-A(6) for the period January 1, 1948 to July 22, 1950.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax confirmed rectification order under s.33-A on February 1, 1958, but modified interest till June 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of his powers under s. 33-A, by order dated February 1, 1958, the Commissioner of Income-tax confirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer rectifying the original order of assessment and imposing liability to pay interest, subject to the modification that interest be paid only till June 13, 1950.

facts.text: Assessee filed petition under Art.226 in Bombay High Court to quash orders.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then moved the High Court of Judicature at Bombay by a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution for issue of a writ certiorari summoning the record of the case and for an order quashing or setting aside the order passed under s. 33-A(2) by the Commissioner of Income-tax and the order passed by the Income-tax Officer under s. 35 and the notice of demand pursuant to that order.

facts.text: Bombay High Court quashed orders following Shantilal Ravji v. M.C. Nair.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Bombay following its earlier judgment in the case of Shantilal Ravji v. M. C. Nair, IV Income-tax Officer, G Ward, Bombay and Another directed that the orders passed by the Income-tax Officer and by the Commissioner of Income-tax be quashed.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art.133 for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the High Court the Commissioner of Income-tax and the Income-tax Officer have, with certificate granted by the High Court, appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Act 25 of 1953 added fifth proviso to s.18-A(6) with retrospective effect from April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: But by Act 25 of 1953 which was enacted with retrospective operation from April 1, 1952, the following proviso was added as the fifth proviso to s. 18-A(6)

facts.text: Rule 48 prescribed by Central Government in December 1953 for discretion under proviso.

anchor.surface_text: the cases in which and circumstances under which the discretion was to be exercised were prescribed by the Central Government by r. 48 in December 1953.

facts.text: Assessee's case fell within terms of r.48.

anchor.surface_text: But the case of the assessee did fall within the terms of r. 48(1) and the Income-tax Officer must in law be bound to consider whether he was entitled to reduction or waiver of interest under the fifth proviso.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, upheld High Court quashing orders.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Mudholkar J. dissented on merits, held ITO competent to rectify under s.35.

anchor.surface_text: agreeing with the Income-tax Commissioner but disagreeing with the High Court, I hold that the Income-tax Officer was competent to rectify the mistake under s. 35.

facts.text: No dispute that ITO was bound to charge penal interest on date of regular assessment.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that according to the law as it stood on the date on which the regular assessment was made the Income-tax Officer was bound to charge penal interest.

facts.text: Provisional assessment under s.23-B made on July 22, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: for the period January 1, 1948 to July 22, 1950.

facts.text: Respondents filed estimate under s.18-A(2) on September 17, 1947 and paid advance tax on September 27, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On September 17, 1947 the respondents filed under s. 18-A(2) an estimate of their income and on September 27, 1947 they made an advance payment of tax on its basis.

facts.text: Revised estimate filed January 10, 1948, further payment January 17, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On January 10, 1948 they filed a revised estimate in pursuance of which they made a further advance payment towards the tax on January 17, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: This Court is invested by the Constitution with appellate jurisdiction of great amplitude exercisable over all courts and tribunals in India. The jurisdiction may be exercised in respect of any judgment, decree, determination, sentence or order in any cause or matter passed by any court or tribunal other than a judgment, determination, sentence or order made or passed by any court or tribunal under any law relating to the Armed Forces Art. 136.

issues.text: Whether a proceeding under Article 226 of the Constitution challenging orders relating to tax liability is a 'civil proceeding' within the meaning of Article 133, permitting the High Court to grant a certificate of appeal to the Supreme Court?

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this appeal counsel for the assessee raised an objection in limine that the appeal filed by the Commissioner and the Income-tax Officer was incompetent. because the High Court had nopower under Art. 133 of the Constitution to certify a proposed appeal against an order in a proceeding commenced by a petition for the issue of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution. It was urged that the proceeding before the High Court was not a civil proceeding within the meaning of Art. 133.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer committed a mistake apparent from the record by not charging interest under s. 18A(6) in the original assessment order, justifying rectification under s. 35, in light of the retrospective fifth proviso to s. 18A(6) deeming discretion to waive interest exercisable from April 1, 1952?

anchor.surface_text: We may now turn to the question which is raised on the merits in this appeal. Section 18-A which was added by the Indian Income-tax (Amendment) Act 11 of 1944 for imposing liability for advance payment of tax enacts by the first sub-section, insofar as it is material, that where there is no provision made for deduction of income-tax at the time of payment, the Income-tax Officer may on or after the commencement of any financial year, by order in writing, require an assessee to pay quarterly to the credit of the Central Government the income-tax and super-tax payable on so much of such income as is included in his total income of the latest previous year in respect of which, he has been assessed.

arguments.claim: The proceeding before the High Court under Art. 226 is not a civil proceeding within the meaning of Art. 133, making the appeal incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this appeal counsel for the assessee raised an objection in limine that the appeal filed by the Commissioner and the Income-tax Officer was incompetent. because the High Court had nopower under Art. 133 of the Constitution to certify a proposed appeal against an order in a proceeding commenced by a petition for the issue of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution. It was urged that the proceeding before the High Court was not a civil proceeding within the meaning of Art. 133.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Court certifies that the case involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution. Counsel relies upon the classifica

arguments.court_reasoning: Civil proceeding includes assertion of civil rights against tax levy; writ jurisdiction does not alter nature.

arguments.claim: Even if writ under Art. 226 is sometimes civil, it is not when seeking relief against tax levy.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative, counsel contended that even if a proceeding for the issue of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution may in certain cases be treated as a civil proceeding, it cannot be so treated when the party aggrieved seeks relief against the levy of tax or revenue claimed to be due to the State.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion of proceeding made in Art. 132 1  and seeks to companytrast it with the phraseology used in Arts. 133 1  134 1 . He says that other proceeding in

arguments.court_reasoning: Tax challenges assert civil rights infringed by unlawful levy; nature depends on right violated, not form.

arguments.claim: Art. 226 writ petition challenging tax orders is a civil proceeding under Art. 133.

anchor.surface_text: The expression civil proceeding in our judgment covers all proceedings in which a party asserts the existence of a civil right conferred by the civil law or by statute, and claims relief for breach thereof.

arguments.court_reasoning: Retrospective proviso deemed discretion at assessment; omission not apparent mistake but presumed consideration/waiver.

arguments.claim: Fifth proviso to s.18A(6) has no effective retrospective operation as rules framed only in Dec 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Attorney-General appearing on behalf of the Commissioner contended that to the fifth proviso to s. 18-A (6) no retrospective operation could effectively be given, because the rules which alone could render the discretion operative were framed for the first time in December 1953.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso expressly retrospective from 1.4.1952; rules effectuate it retrospectively upon framing.

arguments.claim: Power under proviso exercisable without rules until framed, per T. Cajee precedent.

Jormanik Siem... that where power is conferred upon an authority and it is made exercisable in the manner provided by subsidiary legislation, failure to enact such subsidiary legislation will not defeat the power.

arguments.court_reasoning: T. Cajee inapplicable; power here conditional on prescribed cases/circumstances, not absolute until restricted.

arguments.claim: No evidence ITO exercised discretion to waive; omission mere oversight/mistake.

anchor.surface_text: The Attorney-General contended that in any event there was nothing to show that the income-tax officer had purported to exercise his discretion when he passed the order of assessment and did not impose any liability for payment of interest under s. 18-A (6).

arguments.court_reasoning: No explicit exercise, but case within r.48; bound to consider, omission defective but not rectifiable as apparent mistake.

arguments.claim: Retrospective proviso deems discretion at assessment; omission infers waiver, no mistake apparent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Bombay following its earlier judgment in the case of Shantilal Ravji v. M. C. Nair... directed that the orders passed by the Income-tax Officer and by the Commissioner of Income-tax be quashed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . Bombay Dyeing and Manufacturing Company Ltd 1  held in dealing with a case arising under the second proviso to s. 18-A  5   which was also inserted

arguments.court_reasoning: Assessee's case within r.48; ITO bound to consider waiver; retrospective deems provisions extant, omission not mistake.

arguments.claim: Commissioner erred assuming no retrospective effect; but interest leviable till modified date.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of his powers under s. 33-A... the Commissioner of Income-tax confirmed the order... subject to the modification that interest be paid only till June 13, 1950.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: en moved the High Court of Judicature at Bombay by a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution for issue of a writ certiorari summoning the record

arguments.court_reasoning: Commissioner ignored retrospective proviso/r.48; error of law apparent.

arguments.claim: Omission to charge interest was oversight/mistake apparent, rectifiable under s.35 despite retrospective proviso.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, therefore agreeing with the Income-tax Commissioner but disagreeing with the High Court, I hold that the Income-tax Officer was competent to rectify the mistake under s. 35.

arguments.claim: Proviso and r.48 deemed retrospective; omission not exercise of discretion but error as law then required charging.

anchor.surface_text: Even though the proviso and the rule must be deemed to have been in force on April 1, 1952, I find it difficult to agree with the High Court that omission to charge penal interest... must be ascribed to the exercise of discretion by the Income-tax Officer.

holdings.text: A proceeding under Article 226 challenging orders relating to tax liability is a 'civil proceeding' within Article 133 permitting certificate for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The expression civil proceeding in our judgment covers all proceedings in which a party asserts the existence of a civil right conferred by the civil law or by statute, and claims relief for breach thereof. A criminal proceeding on the other hand is ordinarily one in which if carried to its conclusion it may result in the imposition of sentences such as death, imprisonment, fine or forfeiture of property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad interpretation of 'civil proceeding' as asserting civil rights under statute including against tax levy; writ form does not alter nature; rejects exclusion of revenue matters; reviews constitutional scheme Arts 132-134.

holdings.text: Fifth proviso to s.18-A(6) and r.48 have retrospective effect from April 1, 1952, deeming discretion to waive interest exercisable at regular assessment date.

anchor.surface_text: But by Act 25 of 1953 which was enacted with retrospective operation from April 1, 1952, the following proviso was added as the fifth proviso to s. 18-A(6)... the cases in which and circumstances under which the discretion was to be exercised were prescribed by the Central Government by r. 48 in December 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature expressly retrospective; rules effectuate proviso and operate retrospectively upon framing; distinguishes absolute vs conditional power; follows legal fiction principle from precedents.

holdings.text: Assessee's case falls within r.48; ITO bound to consider reduction/waiver of interest under fifth proviso.

anchor.surface_text: But the case of the assessee did fall within the terms of r. 48(1) and the Income-tax Officer must in law be bound to consider whether he was entitled to reduction or waiver of interest under the fifth proviso.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of r.48 terms to facts; retrospective deeming requires consideration at assessment time.

holdings.text: Omission to charge interest not mistake apparent from record justifying s.35 rectification, as retrospective discretion deems possible waiver.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in M. K. Venkatachalam I.T.O. and Another v. Bombay Dyeing... held... that the Income-tax Officer has power under s. 35... even though the mistake was the result of a legal fiction arising from the retrospective operation...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deeming provisions make omission compatible with law (discretion/waiver); distinguishes Venkatachalam (reduced entitlement) as reversed position; no evidence of oversight apparent without further inquiry.

holdings.text: Commissioner erred in law by ignoring retrospective proviso and r.48 applicability.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was brought before the Commissioner of Income-tax and it is unfortunate that the Commissioner in considering the matter under s. 33-A assumed that the amending Act 25 of 1953 had no retrospective operation...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commissioner wrongly held no retrospective effect till rules framed; error apparent on record.

holdings.text: ITO orders under s.35 and Commissioner's confirmation under s.33A quashed; no rectification permissible.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: no apparent mistake due to deemed discretion; upholds High Court.

holdings.text: Omission to charge penal interest was mistake apparent from record; ITO competent to rectify under s.35.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, therefore agreeing with the Income-tax Commissioner but disagreeing with the High Court, I hold that the Income-tax Officer was competent to rectify the mistake under s. 35.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrospective deeming does not convert mandatory duty oversight into discretion exercise without evidence; prima facie error as law then required charging; distinguishes deliberate waiver.

anchor.surface_text: The expression civil proceeding in our judgment covers all proceedings in which a party asserts the existence of a civil right conferred by the civil law or by statute, and claims relief for breach thereof. A criminal proceeding on the other hand is ordinarily one in which if carried to its conclusion it may result in the imposition of sentences such as death, imprisonment, fine or forfeiture of property.
The appeal fails and Is dismissed with companyts. There will be one hearing fee in Civil Appeals Nos. 1003 of 1961 and 1004 of 1963.
